title: 110_s520
content: The "Wild Sky Wilderness Act of 2007" is the short title of this Act. It includes additions to the National Wilderness Preservation System. The "Wild Sky Wilderness Act of 2007" designates approximately 106,000 acres of Federal lands in Washington as wilderness, known as the "Wild Sky Wilderness." The Secretary of Agriculture will file a map and legal description for the wilderness area with the Senate and House committees. The legal description and map for the Wild Sky Wilderness area will be corrected for errors and available for public inspection at the office of the Chief of the Forest Service. SEC. 3. ADMINISTRATION PROVISIONS. SEC. 3. ADMINISTRATION PROVISIONS. Lands designated as wilderness by this Act shall be managed by the Secretary of Agriculture in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this Act. The Secretary may manage the designated area as part of adjacent wilderness areas for administrative efficiencies. The Secretary shall consult for new trails. The Secretary of Agriculture shall establish a trail plan for Forest Service lands to develop hiking and equestrian trails within designated wilderness areas. A report on the trail plan implementation, including priority trails, must be completed within two years. Within the Wild Sky Wilderness, the Secretary of Agriculture is authorized to use helicopter access to construct and maintain a joint Forest Service and Snohomish County telecommunications repeater site for improving communications for safety, health, and emergency services. Floatplane access on Lake Isabel is permitted with reasonable restrictions. The designation under this Act does not affect the operation and maintenance of the existing Evergreen Mountain Lookout. The Evergreen Mountain Lookout will continue to be operated and maintained as it was before the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Agriculture is authorized to acquire lands, prioritize "Priority Acquisition Lands," and adjust boundaries of national forests. Access to private inholdings in the Wild Sky Wilderness must be ensured. Valuation of private lands for acquisition should not consider wilderness area restrictions. Land exchanges are also authorized. The Secretary of Agriculture is authorized to exchange lands with the Chelan County Public Utility District, with specific provisions for the exchange. If the District offers approximately 371.8 acres within the Mt. Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest, the Secretary must accept. Upon acceptance, the Secretary will convey a permanent easement to the District, including helicopter access. The Chelan County Public Utility District is authorized to exchange lands with the Secretary of Agriculture to maintain a telemetry site on 1.82 acres in the Wenatchee National Forest. The exchange will be finalized if the District conveys acceptable title and ensures no hazardous materials on the site. If the District no longer needs the site for monitoring snowpack, the easement will be extinguished. If the Chelan County Public Utility District no longer needs the site for monitoring snowpack, the easement will be extinguished and all rights conveyed by this exchange shall revert to the United States.
